The '''Historiography of Albania''' ({{lang-sq|Historiografia e Shqipërisë}}) or '''Albanian historiography''' ({{lang-sq|Historiografia shqiptare}}) refers to the studies, sources, critical methods and interpretations used by scholars to study the history of [[Albania]].
==Influence of Germany and Austria-Hungary== [[File:Theodor Ippen-Albanian costume.jpg|thumb|Theodor Ippen in [[Shkodër]] wearing a northern Albanian costume]]
[[Theodor Anton Ippen]], who would become a [[Consul (representative)|consul]] of [[Austria-Hungary]] in [[Shkodër|Scutari]] between 1897 and 1903, belonged to the group of Albanologists whose works were published through the state-financed institutes of [[Austria-Hungary]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Blumi |first=Isa |title=Seeing Beyond the River Drin, Sarajevo, Ottoman Albanians and Imperial Rivalry in the Balkans after 1878 |url= http://www.kakanien.ac.at/beitr/fallstudie/IBlumi1.pdf |year=2007 |publisher= Kakanien revisited |location= Austria |page=3|quote= At the center of this Sarajevo-based policy were highly regarded Albanologists such as Theodor Ippen (b.1861), Norbert Jokl (1877-1942) and Franz Nopcsa (1877-1933) who all published influential studies on Albanian language, geography, archeology and history through state-funded institutes in Budapest, Sarajevo and Vienna. |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }}</ref> He participated in writing and disseminating the first history of Albania published on the [[Albanian language]] because he insisted that creating an Albanian national consciousness would be beneficial for the Dual Monarchy.<ref>{{Citation |last=Clayer |first=Nathalie |author= |authorlink= |author-separator= |editor= |editor2= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor-link= |editor2-link= |others= |title=Aux origines du nationalisme albanais: la naissance d'une nation majoritairement musulmane on Europe |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cb6AsVBn7rQC&pg=PA416&dq=%22Albanie,+l%27%C3%A9criture+et+la+diffusion+d%27une+histoire+de+l%27Albanie.%22#v=onepage&q=%22Albanie%2C%20l'%C3%A9criture%20et%20la%20diffusion%20d'une%20histoire%20de%20l'Albanie.%22&f=false |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= January 19, 2011 |edition= |series= |volume= |origyear= |year= 2007 |publisher= Karthala |location= |language= |isbn= 9782845868168 |oclc= |doi= |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page= 416 |pages= |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote=Ce sont aussi les fonctionnaires austro-hongrois qui furent à l'origine du premier livre sur l'histoire de l'Albanie en albanais“. Dès le mois de mai 1897, le consul Ippen insistait auprès du ministre des Affaires étrangères de la Double Monarchie sur les avantages que procurerait, pour l'éveil de la conscience nationale albanaise et donc pour l' action autrichienne en Albanie, l'écriture et la diffusion d'une histoire de l'Albanie. |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }}</ref> Ippen struggled for the establishment of an independent nation-state of Albanians.<ref>{{cite book | title=Ethnologia Balkanica | publisher=Prof. M. Drinov Academic Publishing House | year=1998 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KNXYAAAAMAAJ&dq=ippen+albania&q=%22+he+promoted+the+Albanian+educational+system+and+supported+the+establishment+of+an+independent+Albanian+state%22#search_anchor|page=215 | quote= he promoted the Albanian educational system and supported the establishment of an independent Albanian state}}</ref>
== Modern Albanian historiography ==
There are two main sources of modern Albanian [[historiography]]: intellectuals from the [[Albanian National Awakening]] (''Rilindja'') period and historians from the regime of the [[People's Socialist Republic of Albania]].<ref>{{harvnb|Kressing |2002|p=40}}{{quote|Modern Albanian historiography has two important sources: the thinkers of the 'renaissance' (rilindja) period (1844-1912), and the historians of the Communist regime.}}</ref> From 1878 onward, the national Awakening period galvanised Albanian intellectuals among some who emerged as the first modern Albanian scholars and they were preoccupied with overcoming linguistic and cultural differences between Albanian subgroups (Gegs and Tosks) and religious divisions (Muslim and Christians).<ref name="Kostov40"/> At that time, these scholars lacked access to many primary sources to construct the idea that Albanians were descendants of Illyrians, while Greater Albania was not considered a priority.<ref name="Kostov40"/> Compared with their Balkan counterparts, these Albanian historians were very moderate and alongside politicians mainly had the goal to get socio-political recognition and autonomy for Albanians under Ottoman rule.<ref name="Kostov40">{{cite book|last=Kostov|first=Chris|title=Contested Ethnic Identity: The Case of Macedonian Immigrants in Toronto 1900-1996|year=2010|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=9783034301961|url=https://books.google.com/?id=P-1m1FLtrvsC&pg=PA39&dq=Serb+historians+illyrians#v=onepage&q=Rilindja&f=false|pages=40|ref=harv}}</ref> Two major historical works written by Albanians during this early phase of modern historiography within Albania are Athanase Gegaj's ''L'Albanie et l'Invasion turque au XVe siècle'' (1937) and [[Fan Noli|Fan Noli's]] ''George Castrioti Scanderbeg (1405-1468)'' (1947), both written outside Albania.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gran|first=Peter|title=Beyond Eurocentrism: A New View of Modern World History|year=1996|publisher=Syracuse University Press|page=221}}</ref>
=== Albanian socialist historiography (1945-1992) === Albanian socialist historiography was associated with the Albanian state building project of national legitimation.<ref name="DiLellio11"/> Albanian historiography was based upon the works of a group of Albanian speaking intelligentsia that during the early to mid 19th century developed a national narrative when professional Albanian historians did not exist.<ref name="DiLellio11"/> Balanced approaches to history were not encouraged during the period between the end of [[World War II]] and the death of [[Enver Hohxa]] in 1985.<ref name="Fischer281"/> After the Second World War the communist government trained scholars to become historians and write Albanian history, while due to the political context they were preoccupied with matters relating to national identity.<ref name="DiLellio11"/> In 1959, the first volume on the history of Albania was published that dealt with topics ranging from antiquity until the 19th century and was a major undertaking that was a serious analysis of Greek, Latin, Byzantine and Ottoman sources.<ref name="DiLellio11"/> Elements of national construction dominated parts of the work such as stressing the Illyrians as the ancestors of the Albanians, the existence of an Albanian medieval state and that Albanians during the Ottoman period were an autonomous entity.<ref name="DiLellio11"/> These themes though linked to matters of national identification were not completely unfounded.<ref name="DiLellio11"/> During the communist period, the regime attempted to instill a national consciousness through the scope of a teleological past based upon Illyrian descent, Skanderbeg's resistance to the Ottomans and the nationalist reawakening (''Rilindja'') of the 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref name="SchmidtNeke14"/> Those themes and concepts of history have still continued within a post-communist environment modified and adapted to fit contemporary Albania's aspirations regarding Europe.<ref name="SchmidtNeke14"/> Albanian historiographical scholarship though compromised by political influences did manage to produce reliable information at times. <ref name="DiLellio11">{{harvnb|Di Lellio|2009|p=11}}. "The development of an Albanian scholarly tradition of historians is relatively recent and tightly linked to a project of national legitimation. While a loose international network of Albanian-speaking intellectuals began to develop a national narrative in the first half of the 19th century, professional historians were absent. Only after WWII did the Enver Hoxha regime start to train the scholars who would take up the task of writing Albanian history and, from the outset, the profession was strongly influenced by an authoritarian project of state building; political circumstances kept Albanian historians absorbed by issues of national identity. This does not mean that their work does not yield reliable information. The first volume of the history of Albania that first appeared in 1959 concerns the period from antiquity through the mid-19th century and is a major enterprise based on a serious examination of Greek, Latin, Byzantine and Turkish sources. Its emphasis on the autochthonous character of the Albanians as the sole descendants of the Illyrians and on the existence of an Albanian state in the XII century; and the insistence on the Albanian nation as an autonomous entity during the Ottoman epoch, are all elements of a national construction and in the end inseparable from the process of national identification, but not entirely without foundation."</ref> Of Stalinist Albania, [[Bernd Jürgen Fischer]] stated that it produced good historians though not always good history.<ref name="Fischer281">{{harvnb|Jürgen Fischer|1999|p=281}}{{quote|The political climate in Albania under Enver Hoxha, who ruled Albania from World War II until his death in 1985, did little to encourage a balanced approach to history.}}</ref> Drawing upon themes of national struggles established during the Rilindja period, Albanian socialist historiography centred itself upon the main narrative of nationhood that within history writing included Marxist historical materialism and nationalism.<ref name="Brisku16"/> There were two main notable groups of Albanian historians in that period:<ref>{{harvnb|Jürgen Fischer|1999|p=281}}</ref> # Military historians: Ndreci Plasari and Shyqri Ballvora # Political historians: [[Alex Buda]], Stefanaq Pollo, Arben Puto and Luan Omari.
Alex Buda, who also became a president of the [[Academy of Sciences of Albania]], is sometimes considered as a founder of the Albanian post WWII historiography.<ref name="Keber2010">{{cite book|last1=Hysa|first1=Armanda|last2=Keber|first2=Katarina|title=Historièni seminar 8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QFKZ_D8_Y6AC&pg=PA120|year=2010|publisher=Založba ZRC|isbn=978-961-254-216-0|page=111}}</ref> Buda belonged to a small group of intellectuals allowed by the Albanian communist regime to have access to foreign literature in order to use them to prepare new ideological and theoretical directives for the rest of their colleagues.<ref name="Keber2010-2">{{cite book|last1=Hysa|first1=Armanda|last2=Keber|first2=Katarina|title=Historièni seminar 8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QFKZ_D8_Y6AC&pg=PA120|year=2010|publisher=Založba ZRC|isbn=978-961-254-216-0|page=120}}</ref>
=== Post communist Albanian Historiography ===
When Albanian socialist historiography dealt with people, it tended to see things black and white.<ref>{{harvnb|Jürgen Fischer|1999|p=281}}{{quote|...socialist Albanian historiography tends, when dealing with people, to see things in black and white terms.}}</ref> The legacy of understanding history through such dichotomies has remained for a majority of Albanians which for example they view Skanderbeg and the anti-Ottoman forces as "good" while the Ottomans are "bad".<ref name="SchmidtNeke15"/> The influence of ideology upon Albanian historians during the socialist era of Albanian Historiography can be seen not only in publications published by [[Academy of Sciences of Albania]] (i.e. ''Historia e Shqipërisë'') but also in specialized works published by individual authors like Viron Koka, Mentar Belegu and Ilijaz Fishta.<ref>{{Citation |last=Ilirjani |first= Altin |author2= Arolda Elbasani, Ridvan Peshkopia |author-separator= |editor= |editor2= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor-link= |editor2-link= |others= |title=Albanian Journal of Politics |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e_TKBd1prK0C&pg=PA178&dq=historiography+albania#v=onepage&q=historiography%20albania&f=false |volume=1 |year=2010 |publisher= Shoqata Shqiptare e Shkencave Politike |location=Chapel Hill, NC |language= |isbn= 9780977666225|oclc=70817932 |page=178 |quote=... the ideologically tingled historiography of socialist-era Albanian historians, as evidenced not only in official publications issued by the Academy of Sciences of Albania, like in....Historia e Shqipërisë, but also in more specialized works by authors such as...}}</ref> Due to that legacy, [[Robert Elsie]] emphasized that there was no reliable and objective historiography in Albania which could serve as a basis for his historical dictionary of Albania he compiled and published in 2010.<ref>{{harvnb|Elsie|2010|p=xi}}{{quote|...Compiling a historical dictionary for a country... as Albania... because there is still no objective and reliable historiography in Albania.}}</ref> [[Oliver Jens Schmitt]] stated that the post-World War II Albanian regime propagated the official version of the past using all available means. People in Albania were subjected to state organized indoctrination and propaganda. Schmitt explained that because of political influence it was impossible to organize open discussion about socialist historiography, while those who attempted to criticize it would be denounced often as non-professionals or foreigners with evil objectives.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jens|first=Oliver|author2=Ben Andoni|title=Historia shqiptare-një histori e hapur|journal=ResPublica|url=http://respublica.al/opinion/2013/02/11/historia-shqiptare-nje-histori-e-hapur|accessdate=6 February 2014|language=Albanian|year=2013|quote=Mbas 1945, për herë të parë në historinë e Shqipërisë, Shteti përdorte të gjitha mjetet e tij për të prodhuar dhe propaganduar versionin e tij zyrtar të së shkuarës. Fatkeqësisht, kjo ndodhte në një shtet Orvellian, ku historianët ishin thjesht mjete në duart e diktatorit, i cili personalisht diktonte linjat kryesore të interpretimit. Kjo ishte periudha ku shumë nga Shqiptarët u konfrontuan për herë të parë me historinë – e sistemi shkollor i shtetit të ri integroi për herë të parë gjithashtu fëmijë nga zonat rurale dhe familjet e varfra. ... Kritikët ose u denoncuan si jo-profesionistë (sepse ata nuk u rekrutuan në institucionet kërkimore për shkak të mendimeve të tyre ndryshe) apo si të huaj me qëllime të errëta.}}</ref> The influence of such historical myths still remain which for example in 2009 Schmitt was severely criticised in Albania after producing an academic biography that challenged the traditional Albanian concept of Skanderbeg.<ref name="SchmidtNeke14">{{harvnb|Schmidt-Neke|2014|p=14.}}</ref> Post-communist Albanian historiography has attempted to move away from previous political influences of the Hoxha era and shift the discipline toward a more scientific methodological direction, however, themes of national struggles continue.<ref name="Brisku16">{{harvnb|Brisku|2013|p=16}}.</ref> Political pressures have been placed upon contemporary Albanian historiography.<ref name="Brisku17"/> For example the Albanian government in 2013 reformed the Academy of Sciences by allowing it to influence the scholarship of historians by urging them to rewrite history (mostly in relation to the modern period).<ref name="Brisku17"/> Those moves caused heated debate among historians of which one group viewing the initial intent as being a move to place aside distortions of the past that assisted in empowering the communists and another group seeing it as a repeat of the communist regime's politicisation of history.<ref name="Brisku17">{{harvnb|Brisku|2013|p=17}}.</ref>
== Themes ==
=== Early Albanian history === {{Main article|Origin of the Albanians}}
The picture created by [[Science and technology in Albania|Albanian science]] about the early history of [[Albanians]] is simplified, uncritical and has appearances of fabrication.<ref>{{harvnb|Bartl|2001|p=17}}{{quote|Слика коју албанска наука ствара о раној историјисопственог народа је поједностављена, некритичка и делује исконструисано.}}</ref> Albanian scholars have continuously asserted and claimed antecedence of [[Albanian culture]] over [[Slavic culture|Slav culture]].<ref>{{harvnb|Elsie|2004|p=xvii}}{{quote|Albanian scholars ever ready to assert antecedence of their culture over that of the Slavs }}</ref> The official Albanian historiography, which influenced many Albanians, emphasizes that Albanians have always lived in Albania and supports the hypothesis that Albanians are descendants of [[Illyrians]], while some non-Albanian scholars consider the question of the origin of Albanians to be unsolved.<ref>{{harvnb|Kressing |2002|p=41}}{{quote|The official historiography claims that Albanians have always lived in Albania and therefore gives credit to the thesis that they are the descendants of the Illyrians...However, non-Albanian researchers consider the question of Illyrian or Thracian origin of the Albanians to be unsolved...Nevertheless, this version of history has influenced many Albanians}}</ref>
=== Ottoman period and Islam in Albania === {{Main article|Islamization of Albania|Islam in Albania#Debates about Islam and contemporary Albanian identity}}
The image of [[Islam]] produced by both main sources of modern Albanian historiography was neither objective nor positive.<ref>{{harvnb|Kressing |2002|p=40}}{{quote|Neither of them produced an objective and positive image of Islam.}}</ref> Although the [[Albanian Communists|communist]] [[Fall of communism in Albania|regime fell]] (1992) in Albania, contemporary Albanian historians have still held onto inherited [[stereotypes]] and [[myths]] regarding Islam from Albanian socialist historiography.<ref>{{harvnb|Kressing |2002|p=41}}{{quote|Since the fall of Communism, Albanian historians have not started to free themselves from their inherited stereotypes. This explains why contemporary history, when it comes to Islam, is still the prisoner of myths.}}</ref>
Albanian historiographical myths regarding Islam include:<ref>{{harvnb|Kressing |2002|p=41}}{{quote|One of these myths is that Islam is an alien element of Albanian culture imported by the Ottomans. The reason is that Albanians were originally Christian (Saint Paul visited Illyria). Other myths say that they had converted for a number of reasons which had nothing to do with religion. They were opportunists. They wanted to escape the taxes imposed on Christians and to benefit from the many advantages attached to being Muslim in a Muslim society. It is said also that they were forced by the Ottomans to embrace Islam. Those who converted are often presented as traitors to the true spirit of the nation. Another important myth is the weakness of Albanians’ religious feeling. Communists worked hard to show that in their history national feeling was always more important for Albanians than religious feeling. In their propaganda, they did not hesitate to distort the ideas of the rilindja writers. As an example, they used - out of context - the famous declaration of Pashko Vasa Shkodrani: ‘The religion of the Albanians is Albanianism’. Actually, he wanted to encourage national unity while still respecting each person’s religious belief.}}</ref> # Islam was imported by the [[Ottomans]] and is an alien element of Albanian culture. # Albanians converted from [[Christianity]] to Islam not because of their religious feelings though instead for other opportunistic reasons or because they were sometimes forced to do so. # Albanian religious sentiments are weak because Albanian national feeling was always more important for Albanians than their religious adherence and affiliations.
Numerous historians from Albania with nationalist perspectives (Ramadan Marmallaku, Kristo Frasheri, Skender Anamali, Stefanaq Pollo, Skender Rizaj and Arben Puto) intentionally emphasized "the Turkish savagery" and "heroic Christian resistance against the Osmanli state in Albania".<ref>{{harvnb|Kopanski|1997|p=192}}{{quote|Albanian nationalist historians like Ramadan Marmallaku, Kristo Frasheri, Skender Anamali, Stefanaq Pollo, Skender Rizaj and Arben Puto in their books deliberately emphasized "the Turkish savagery" and "heroic Christian resistance against the Osmanli state in Albania".}}</ref> Albanian historiography tends to ignore religiously inspired enmity between Albanians of different faiths.<ref>{{harvnb|Schwandner-Sievers|2002|p=62}}{{quote|...there are many instances of religiously inspired animosities, which present day Albanian historiography tends to ignore.}}</ref> Trends from Albanian nationalist historiography composed by scholars during and of the communist era onward linger on that interpret Ottoman rule as being the "yoke" period, akin to other Balkan historiographies.<ref name="SchmidtNeke15">{{harvnb|Schmidt-Neke|2014|p=15.}}</ref>
=== Skanderbeg ===
Although the [[Myth of Skanderbeg]] had little to do with the reality of historical Skanderbeg, it was incorporated in works about [[history of Albania]].<ref>{{Citation |last= Bartl |first= Peter |author= |authorlink= |author-separator= |editor= |editor2= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor-link= |editor2-link= |others= |title=Bartl, Peter: review of: Schmitt, Oliver Jens, Skanderbeg. Der neue Alexander auf dem Balkan |url=http://www.recensio.net/rezensionen/zeitschriften/sudost-forschungen.-internationale-zeitschrift-fur-geschichte-kultur-und-landeskunde-sudosteuropas/--/68-2009/ReviewMonograph764076972/@@generate-pdf-recension?language=fr |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume= |origyear= |year= 2009 |publisher= |location= |language= German |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page= |pages= |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= Dieser Mythos hatte mit der historischen Realität wenig zu tun, er fand aber nichtsdestotrotz Eingang auch in die albanische Geschichtsschreibung. [This myth had a little to do with the historical reality, but it was nonetheless included in the Albanian history too.] |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }}</ref>
=== Treaty of London === {{Main article|Treaty of London (1913)}}
The Treaty of London interpreted by nationalist Albanian historiography symbolizes the partition of the Albanian nation into three parts.<ref>{{Citation |last= Ersoy |first= Ahmet |author2= Maciej Górny; Vangelis Kechriotis |title=Modernism : the creation of nation-states |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8j-Uemo6SfoC&pg=PA237&dq=historiography+albania#v=onepage&q=historiography%20albania&f=false |year=2010 |publisher=Central European University Press |location= Budapest ; New York |isbn=9781441684110 |oclc=699519530 |pages=236, 237 |quote=Decisions of the London ...In nationalist Albanian historiography, this symbolizes the partition of the nation into three parts; Kosovo was annexed by Serbia, Çamëria (Gr. Tsamouria) was annexed by Greece, and the remaining part became the state of Albania }}</ref>
=== Other ===
The Serbian argument that Kosovo was first settled by the Albanians in the 17th century is rejected by modern Albanian historiography.<ref name="Singh2009">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Jasvir|authorlink=|title=Problem of Ethicity: Role of United Nations in Kosovo Crisis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pm-9_uxFw5UC&pg=PA84|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Dr. Jasvir Singh|isbn=978-81-7142-701-7|page=84|quote=Modern Albanian historiography rejects the Serbian argument that the Albanians first settled in Kosovo in seventeenth}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=May 2015}}
A '''hydraulic empire''' (also known as a '''hydraulic despotism''', or '''water monopoly empire''') is a social or government structure which maintains power and control through exclusive control over access to water. It arises through the need for [[flood]] control and [[irrigation]], which requires central coordination and a specialized [[bureaucracy]].<ref name="Wittfogel">{{cite book | last = Wittfogel | first = Karl | authorlink = Karl August Wittfogel | title = Oriental despotism; a comparative study of total power | publisher = Random House | year = 1957 | location = New York | pages = | url = | isbn = 978-0-394-74701-9}}</ref>
Often associated with these terms and concepts is the notion of a ''water dynasty''. This body is a political structure which is commonly characterized by a system of hierarchy and control often based on class or caste. Power, both over resources (food, water, energy) and a means of enforcement such as the military are vital for the maintenance of control.
== Civilizations ==
A developed hydraulic civilization maintains control over its population by means of controlling the supply of water. The term was coined by the [[German-American]] historian [[Karl August Wittfogel]] (1896–1988), in his book ''[[Oriental Despotism (book)|Oriental Despotism]]'' (1957). Wittfogel asserted that such "hydraulic civilizations"—although they were neither all located in the Orient nor characteristic of all Oriental societies—were essentially different from those of the Western world.
Most of the [[first civilization]]s in history, such as [[Ancient Egypt]], [[History of Somalia#Ancient|Ancient Somalia]], Sri Lanka, [[Mesopotamia]], China and [[Pre-Columbian Mexico]] and [[Pre-Columbian Peru|Peru]], are believed to have been hydraulic empires.{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} The [[Indus Valley civilization]] is often considered a hydraulic empire despite a lack of evidence of irrigation (as this evidence may have been lost in time due to flood damage).{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} Most hydraulic empires existed in arid or [[desert]] regions, but imperial China also had some such characteristics, due to the exacting needs of rice cultivation.
The [[Ajuran Sultanate]] of the [[Horn of Africa]] was the only hydraulic empire in Africa. A hydraulic empire that rose in the 13th century AD, Ajuran monopolized the water resources of the [[Jubba River|Jubba]] and [[Shebelle River]]s. Through [[hydraulic engineering]], it also constructed many of the [[limestone]] [[Water well|wells]] and [[cistern]]s of the state that are still operative and in use today. Its rulers developed new systems for agriculture and taxation, which continued to be used in parts of the Horn of Africa as late as the 19th century.<ref name="His 40">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FlL2vE_qRQ8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The History of Somalia |page=26 |accessdate=2014-02-14|isbn=9780313378577 |last1=Njoku |first1=Raphael Chijioke |year=2013 }}</ref>
==Analysis== {{Refimprove section|date=July 2013}} Wittfogel argues that climate caused some parts of the world to develop higher levels of civilization than others. He is known for claiming that climate in the Orient led to despotic rule. This environmental determinism comes to bear when considering that in those societies where the most control was exhibited, this was commonly the case due to the central role of the resource in economic processes and its environmentally limited, or constrained nature. This made controlling supply and demand easier and allowed a more complete monopoly to be established, as well as preventing the use of alternative resources to compensate. However, Diamond {{Reference or Citation needed|date=October 2018}} points out that complex irrigation projects predated states in Madagascar, Mexico, China and Mesopotamia.
The typical hydraulic empire government, in Wittfogel's thesis, is extremely centralized, with no trace of an independent aristocracy – in contrast to the decentralized [[feudalism]] of medieval Europe. Though tribal societies had structures that were usually personal in nature, exercised by a patriarch over a tribal group related by various degrees of kinship, hydraulic hierarchies gave rise to the established permanent institution of impersonal government. Popular revolution in such a state was impossible: a dynasty might die out or be overthrown by force, but the new regime would differ very little from the old one. Hydraulic empires were only ever destroyed by foreign conquerors.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}
Wittfogel's ideas, when applied to China, have been harshly criticized by scholars such as [[Joseph Needham]] who argued essentially that Wittfogel was operating from ignorance of basic [[History of China|Chinese history]]. Needham argued that the Chinese government was not despotic, was not dominated by a priesthood, had lots of peasant rebellions, and that Wittfogel's perspective does not address the necessity and presence of bureaucracy in modern Western civilization.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} [[Robert L. Carneiro]] was also critical of Wittfogel's theory, writing in ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' in August 1970: "This theory has recently run into difficulties. Archeological evidence now makes it appear that in at least three of the areas that Wittfogel cites as exemplifying his "hydraulic hypothesis"—Mesopotamia, China, and Mexico—full-fledged states developed well before large-scale irrigation".<ref name="Science 21 August 1970">{{cite journal |last= Carneiro |first= Robert L. |title= A Theory of the Origin of the State |url= http://www.anthonyflood.com/carneirooriginstate.htm | date=21 August 1970|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=169|issue= 3947|pages= 733–738 |accessdate=29 April 2015 |doi=10.1126/science.169.3947.733 |pmid=17820299}}</ref> With regard to [[Mesopotamia]], Carneiro cited [[Robert McCormick Adams, Jr.]], who had concluded: "In short, there is nothing to suggest that the rise of dynastic authority in southern Mesopotamia was linked to the administrative requirements of a major canal system."<ref name="Science 21 August 1970"/><ref name="City Invincible">{{cite book| editor1 = Carl Hermann Kraeling | editor2= Robert M. Adams |title= City Invincible: A Symposium on Urbanization and Cultural Development in the Ancient Near East. Held at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, December 4-7, 1958. | date = 1960 | publisher = University of Chicago Press | page = 281| asin= B000OYXA5E }}</ref> On China, which Carneiro called "the prototypical area for Wittfogel's hydraulic theories", he quoted [[Jacques Gernet]] who had recently written: “although the establishment of a system of regulation of water courses and irrigation, and the control of this system, may have affected the political constitution of the military states and imperial China, the fact remains that, historically, it was the pre-existing state structures and the large, well-trained labour force provided by the armies that made the great irrigation projects possible”.<ref name="Science 21 August 1970"/><ref name="Jacques Gernet">{{cite book| last = Gernet |first= Jacques | others= Trans. Raymond Rudorff |title= Ancient China From the Beginnings to the Empire | date = 1968| publisher = Faber and Faber | location= London| page = 92| asin= B000BWHHEY }}</ref> Turning to Mexico, Carneiro wrote: “large-scale irrigation systems do not appear to antedate the Classic period, whereas it is clear that the first states arose in the preceding Formative or Pre-Classic period”.<ref name="Science 21 August 1970"/> Of hydraulic empires generally, Carneiro commented: "This is not to say, of course, that large-scale irrigation, where it occurred, did not contribute significantly to increasing the power and scope of the state. It unquestionably did. To the extent that Wittfogel limits himself to this contention, I have no quarrel with him whatever. However, the point at issue is not how the state increased its power but how it arose in the first place. And to this issue the hydraulic hypothesis does not appear to hold the key."<ref name="Science 21 August 1970"/>
The same elements of resource control central to hydraulic empire were also central to Europe's colonization of much of the global South. Colonies were resource rich areas located on the periphery, and the contemporary models of core-periphery interaction were focused on the extraction and control of these resources for the use of the core.<ref>Myrdal, Gunner. 1957. ''Economic Theory and Under-developed Regions.'' London: Gerald Duckworth and Co. Ltd.</ref> This was accomplished through a type of agro-managerial despotism with close connections to debates around hydraulic empire.
==In fiction== {{In popular culture|section|date=June 2017}} {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2017}} *The protagonist in Larry Niven's ''[[A World Out of Time]]'' (1976) describes the concept of a water-monopoly empire to the antagonist. This becomes a major plot point. In his book ''[[Destiny's Road]]'' (1998), potassium (a trace nutrient) takes the place of water.{{Citation needed|date=September 2014}} *In [[S. M. Stirling]]'s novel ''[[Drakon (novel)|Drakon]]'' (1996), the ''drakensis'' Gwendolyn Ingolfson comments on Wittfogel's ''[[Karl August Wittfogel#The Asiatic Mode of Production|Oriental Despotism]]'': "Interesting analysis. Very acute…my ancestors would probably have killed him." * In the ''[[Dune (franchise)|Dune]]'' science fiction series, created by [[Frank Herbert]], water is a source of power and contention on the desert planet [[Arrakis]]. More importantly, a drug called [[Melange (fictional drug)|melange]], found only on that planet, is the key commodity in interplanetary commerce. This makes whoever controls Arrakis ruler of a hydraulic empire on Arrakis and, by effect, the empire of the entire known universe. At many places in the books some variant of the following is said of melange: "He who controls it, controls our destiny." * In the [[James Bond]] film ''[[Quantum of Solace]]'', the primary antagonist Dominic Greene plots a coup d'état in [[Bolivia]] in order to seize control of its water supply. * The leader of a small bastion of post-apocalyptic human activity in ''[[The Book of Eli]]'' has founded and maintained dominion of his town—and plans to expand his power—through the control of rare underground springs that only he knows about. * One of the faction leaders of ''[[Fallout: New Vegas]]'', Mr. House, holds a grip over another faction, the [[New California Republic]], with a one-sided deal where the NCR maintains and protects Hoover Dam while he gets more than enough free energy and water to maintain New Vegas. * The cult-leader Immortan Joe from ''[[Mad Max: Fury Road]]'' has monopolized fresh water resources extracted from deep underground, using it as a mechanism of control and for hydroponic agriculture in the post-apocalyptic wasteland. * The fifth episode of the third season of the ''[[Mission: Impossible]]'' television series, titled "The Execution", the Impossible Mission Force must stop a gangster from taking over the food distribution throughout the United States. * The mega-corporation Water and Power from ''[[Tank Girl]]'' hunts down and imprisons or kills anyone caught with a well or other means of obtaining water on their own. * The main antagonist of ''[[Turbo Kid]]'' kills anyone he finds out is obtaining fresh water within his domain without his permission. * In [[The_Expanse_(TV_series)|The Expanse]] 'Belters', who live in various space stations and small moons and asteroids throughout the solar system rely on imported water and air and are subject to rationing as a form of social pacification.

[[File:Comissió avaluadora de la consulta d'Arenys de Munt.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Jordi Bilbeny]] (far left) at the count of the [[Catalan independence referendums, 2009–11|2009 independence referendum]] in [[Arenys de Munt]]]] The '''Institut Nova Història''' (INH) is a [[Catalonia|Catalan]] cultural [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]] with headquarters in [[Barcelona]]. Its members, of which the most prominent is the Catalan nationalist writer [[Jordi Bilbeny]], hold that history has been systematically manipulated by the Spanish (or "Castilian") state since the 15th century to eliminate the Catalan contribution to world history. They claim that major historical figures, including [[Christopher Columbus]], [[Erasmus]], [[Miguel de Cervantes]], [[William Shakespeare]], [[Leonardo da Vinci]], [[Teresa of Ávila|Saint Teresa of Ávila]] and others were Catalan. The institute's work has been criticised as [[pseudohistory]].
The institute promotes research, study and dissemination of ideas about Catalan influence on history through publications, conferences and symposia, in particular the annual "Symposium on the Catalan Discovery of America" in [[Arenys de Munt]]. It is funded by the [[Generalitat de Catalunya|Catalan autonomous government]], and has received support from [[Catalan nationalism|Catalan nationalist]] politicians.
== History == [[File:Víctor Cucurull 2011 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Víctor Cucurull in 2011]] The INH was created in 2007 following a split in the Foundation of Historical Studies of Catalonia.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mas|first=Andreu|title =Colom era català, barceloní, i d'una nissaga noble|url=http://www.codic.cat/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/codic-cat-2009-11-03-El-Punt-Noticia-Colom-era-Catala-Barceloni-i-d-una-nissaga-noble-98608.pdf|work=El Punt|date =3 November 2009|language = Catalan}}</ref> The principal researcher of the INH is [[Jordi Bilbeny]], a member of the "Arenysian Movement for Self-Determination", a local independentist movement, and of the Arenys de Munt's [[Popular Unity Candidacy]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.llibertat.cat/2009/11/ximenis-i-bilbeny-analitzen-les-consultes-en-una-xerrada-a-besalu-aquest-divendres-8026|title= imenis i Bilbeny analitzen les consultes en una xerrada a Besalú aquest divendres|work=Llibertat.cat|date=3 November 2009|language=Catalan|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140804160245/http://www.llibertat.cat/2009/11/ximenis-i-bilbeny-analitzen-les-consultes-en-una-xerrada-a-besalu-aquest-divendres-8026|archive-date=4 August 2014}}</ref> who launched the "Symposium on the Catalan Discovery of America" in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.elpuntavui.cat/noticia/article/5-cultura/19-cultura/331617-error-intencionat.html|title=Error intencionat? Un simposi d'historiadors a Arenys de Mar debatrà el possible origen català de Colom i per què es va negar|work=El Punt Avui|date=16 November 2010|language=Catalan}}</ref> From its inception, the INH has undertaken the study and dissemination of the Catalan background and/or culture of [[Christopher Columbus]], [[Miguel de Cervantes]], ''[[Lazarillo de Tormes]]'', all topics put forward by Bilbeny.<ref name=DB091130>{{cite news|last=Marí|first=Francesca|title=Castella no té història universal|work=dBalears|date=30 November 2009 |language = Catalan|url=http://dbalears.cat/actualitat/cultura/castella-no-te-historia-universal.html}}</ref> The president of the Institute is Albert Codinas,<ref name=Segura>{{cite news |last=Segura |first=Cristián |date= 26 November 2014 |title=Were Columbus, Cervantes and Leonardo da Vinci really Catalan? |url= https://elpais.com/elpais/2014/11/25/inenglish/1416926983_487701.html|work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref> vice president of the {{lang|ca|Fundació Catalunya Estat}}, secretary of the {{lang|ca|Associació Catalunya 2014}}, and co-founder of the Platform for the Right to Decide.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marfull i Pujadas|first=Andreu|title=Entrevista a l'Albert Codinas a la revista LA FADA de Sarrià|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Entrevista-a-l’Albert-Codinas-a-la-revista-LA-FADA-de-Sarria|website=Institut Nova Història|date=26 August 2014|language = Catalan|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122175709/http://www.inh.cat/articles/Entrevista-a-l%E2%80%99Albert-Codinas-a-la-revista-LA-FADA-de-Sarria|archive-date =22 November 2014}}</ref> Víctor Cucurull, another researcher,<ref>{{cite news|last=Alonso de la Torre|first= J. R.|title=Pizarro era de Cataluña|url=http://www.hoy.es/extremadura/201409/03/pizarro-cataluna-20140903001236-v.html|work=hoy.es| date=3 September 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref> is president of the {{lang|ca|Fundació Societat i Cultura}},<ref>{{cite web|title=Conferència amb Víctor Cucurull|url=http://www.vilafrancaxindependencia.cat/index.php/7-noticies/36-conferencia-amb-victor-cucurull |website=ANC Vilafranca per la Independència|date=13 February 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref> and a member of the national secretariat of the [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|Catalan National Assembly]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Segura|first=Cristian |title=Complot històric contra Catalunya|url=http://cat.elpais.com/cat/2014/11/23/cultura/1416763119_988379.html|work=El País| date=23 November 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref>
The INH has supported and organized, together with the municipality of [[Arenys de Munt]], the ''Simposis sobre la descoberta catalana d'Amèrica'' (Symposium on the Catalan Discovery of America),<ref name=Segura/> held since 2001, where speakers present research on the [[Discovery of the Americas]] by the Catalans.<ref name=INH090501>{{cite web|last=Bassa|first=David|title=Manifest a favor del Simposi d'Arenys de Munt|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Manifest-a-favor-del-Simposi-d-Arenys-de-Munt |website= Institut Nova Història|date=1 May 2009|language=Catalan|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140804161707/http://www.inh.cat/articles/Manifest-a-favor-del-Simposi-d-Arenys-de-Munt|archive-date=4 August 2014}}</ref> In 2013, the Institute organized the first Universitat Nova Història in [[Pla de l'Estany]], under the sponsorship of the [[Province of Girona|Provincial Council of Girona]], the municipality of [[Arenys de Mar]], Cercle Català de Negocis (Catalan Business Circle), asamblea.cat, the Regional Council of [[Pla de l'Estany]] and Fundació Catalunya Estat.<ref name=llib>{{cite news| title = Primera Universitat Nova Història durant l'agost|url=http://www.llibertat.cat/2013/07/primera-universitat-nova-historia-durant-l-agost-a-crespia-22225 |work=llibertat.cat |date =3 July 2013|language = Catalan| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130925053315/http://www.llibertat.cat/2013/07/primera-universitat-nova-historia-durant-l-agost-a-crespia-22225|archive-date=25 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = 1a Universitat Nova Història, de l'1 al 4 d'agost a Crespià|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/1a-Universitat-Nova-Historia,-de-l%271-al-4-d%27agost-a-Crespia|website= Institut Nova Història|date=2 July 2013|language=Catalan}}</ref>
== Theories == [[File:Barcelona - Plaça Portal de la Pau - View West on Columbus Statue 1888.jpg|thumb|120px|Statue of [[Christopher Columbus]] in Barcelona]] [[File:Mona Lisa, by Leonardo da Vinci, from C2RMF retouched.jpg|thumb|120px|The [[Mona Lisa]], by [[Leonardo da Vinci]]]] The INH considers that the history of Catalonia has been manipulated and distorted since the end of the 15th century to favour the construct of a centralised Spanish ("Castilian") state. By minimising the role of Catalonia—or the [[Crown of Aragon]]—in Spanish collective history through falsification, concealment and censorship or "appropriation" of certain historical episodes, the prevalence of Castilian ideology is established.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pere Forès i Malleu|first=Pere|title = Esborrant la traça catalana|magazine=Presència|location=Barcelona|number=2021|date=19 November 2010|pages=28–31|id= GI-143-1965}}</ref> Among its claims are: *That [[Christopher Columbus]], who discovered the Americas, was a Catalan;<ref name=Garín/><ref name=Crameri>{{cite journal|last=Crameri|first=Kathryn|date=2012|title=History Written by the Losers: History, Memory, Myth and Independence in Twenty-First Century Catalonia. |url=https://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/handle/11299/184381/hiol_11_02_crameri_history_written_by_the_losers.pdf?sequence=1|journal=Hispanic Issues on Line| number=11|page= 39 |issn=1931-8006 |publisher=University of Minnesota|location=Minnesota|access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref> that his real name was Joan Colom i Bertran; that he was "a Catalan noble that fought against [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]] in the [[Catalan Civil War]] of 1462-1472 and so needed to change his identity in order to avoid persecution by royalist forces"; and that he sailed from the port of [[Pals]] rather than from [[Palos de Moguer]].<ref name=Rodríguez/> According to INH, [[Erasmus]] of Rotterdam was actually named Ferran, and was the second son of this Joan Colom i Bertran (Columbus).<ref name=EC140630>{{cite news |last=Fernández|first=Antonio|title=Las teorías independentistas que convierten en catalanes a personajes históricos|url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2014-06-30/las-teorias-independentistas-que-convierten-en-catalanes-a-personajes-historicos_153935/|work=El Confidencial|date=30 June 2014| language = Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last= Mayolas|first=Pep|title=Pep Mayolas: «La meva hipòtesi és que Erasme era català i fill d’En Colom»|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Pep-Mayolas:-La-meva-hipotesi-es-que-Erasme-era-catala-i-fill-d|accessdate=16 November 2018|website=Intitut Nova Història|date=21 April 2014|language=catalán}}</ref> *That [[Hernán Cortés]] was actually Ferran Cortès, a Catalan noble;<ref name=Segura/><ref>{{cite news|title=Hernán Cortés también era catalán y se llamaba Ferran Cortès|url=http://www.elmanifiesto.com/articulos.asp?idarticulo=4689 |work=elmanifiesto.com|date=29 April 2014|language = Spanish}}</ref> [[Francisco Pizarro]] was Francesc Pinós De So i Carròs; [[Diego de Almagro]]'s real name was Jaume d'Aragó-Dalmau;<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayolas|first=Pep|title=Francisco Pizarro i Diego de Almagro, dos conquistadors de nissaga reial catalana|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Francisco-Pizarro-i-Diego-de-Almagro,-dos-conquistadors-de-nissaga-reial-catalana|website=Institut Nova Història|date=17 April 2014| language=Catalan}}</ref> [[Amerigo Vespucci]]'s last name was a distortion of the surname "Despuig", and his voyage to the new world was made in the name of the "King of Catalonia".<ref name=Segura/><ref name=EC140630/><ref>{{cite web|author=Jordi Bilbeny|title=Américo Vespuche era un Despuig. Primera part de l'estudi d'en Jordi Bilbeny|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Americo-Vespuche-era-un-Despuig.-Primera-part-de-l%27estudi-d%27en-Jordi-Bilbeny|website= Institut Nova Història|date=22 February 2012|language=Catalan}}</ref> Thus, the feat of discovery and conquest was accomplished entirely by Catalans, the only people who sailed to the Americas before 1518.<ref name=DB091130/> *That [[Miguel de Cervantes]] was a Catalan,<ref name=Garín/><ref name=Crameri/> whose real name was Joan Miquel Servent, and who was a native of [[Xixona]];<ref>{{cite web |last=Esquivel|first= Francisco|title=Cervantes, català|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Cervantes,-catala- |website=Institut Nova Història|date=16 October 2012|language=Catalan}}</ref> that ''[[Don Quixote]]'' was a faulty translation of the original work in Catalan, ''El Quixot'', which was destroyed by the Castilians,<ref>{{cite web|last=Villarrodà|first= Jordi|title=El Quixot és la traducció d’una obra catalana, d’en Joan Miquel Servent|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/%27El-Quixot-es-la-traduccio-d |website= Institut Nova Història | date =30 January 2013|language = Catalan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Riera|first=José|title=El Quixot és una mala traducció de l'original en català|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/El-Quixot-es-una-mala-traduccio-de-l%27original-en-catala|website=Institut Nova Història|date=1 March 2010|language=Catalan}}</ref> and "passed off as Castilian".<ref name=Segura/> In fact, according to Miquel Izquierdo i Perán from INH, Servent had to flee Spain and once in England, published his works under the pseudonym “[[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]”, thereby making Servent, Cervantes and Shakespeare one and the same person.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bernat Puigtobella|first=Bernat |title=Shakespeare era català|url=http://www.nuvol.com/opinio/shakespeare-era-catala/|work=Punt de Llibre|language=catalán|date=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Nerín|first=Gustau|title=Van ser Cervantes i Shakespeare la mateixa persona?|url=http://www.elnacional.cat/ca/cultura-idees-arts/cervantes-shakespeare-miquel-izquierdo_101410_102.html|work=El Nacional.cat|language=ES|date=7 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fernández|first=Laura|title=Un libro sostiene que Cervantes y Shakespeare eran la misma persona: un catalán|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2016/04/13/570e97d6ca4741d7718b461d.html|work=El Mundo|language=ES|date=13 April 2016}}</ref> *That [[Leonardo da Vinci]] was Catalan, born in a town near Montserrat, such as [[Manresa]], [[Vic]] or [[La Garriga]];<ref name=Mendo>{{cite news| last=Mendo|first=A.|title=Colón y Da Vinci son catalanes, según un grupo de historiadores nacionalistas|url=http://www.antena3.com/noticias/espana/colon-vinci-son-catalanes-segun-grupo-historiadores-nacionalistas_2014070800252.html|work=Antena 3|date=8 July 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Mirror>{{cite web|first=Jose Luis|last=Espejo|title=Leonardo, Montserrat i el secret de la Gioconda|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Leonardo,-Montserrat-i-el-secret-de-la-Gioconda |website= Institut Nova Història|date=5 May 2009|language=Catalan}}</ref><ref name=Segura/><ref name="El Punt">{{cite web|title=Jordi Bilbeny «Desmuntant Leonardo» a El Punt Avui TV|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Jordi-Bilbeny-Desmuntant-Leonardo-a-El-Punt-Avui-TV |website=Institut Nova Història|date=4 August 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref> that [[Mona Lisa]] was actually [[Isabella of Aragon, Duchess of Milan|Isabella of Aragon]]; that the mountains depicted at the bottom of the portrait were the [[Montserrat (mountain)|Montserrat mountain range]]; and that Da Vinci's coat of arms was very similar to that of the "Catalan Royal House".<ref name=Segura/> These ideas were put forward in a 2014 documentary, ''Desmutant Leonardo ''(Deconstructing Leonardo), on {{lang|ca|El Punt Avui TV}}.<ref name="Cat Radio">{{cite web|title = Parlem de 'Desmuntant Leonardo' a Catalunya Ràdio|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Parlem-de-%27Desmuntant-Leonardo%27-a-Catalunya-Radio|website = Institut Nova Història|date=July 28, 2014|language=Catalan}}; Interview with Jordi Bilbeny at [[Catalunya Ràdio]].</ref> *That the original versions of ''[[La Celestina]]'' and ''[[Lazarillo de Tormes]]''—the latter having been written by Joan Timoneda—were in Catalan and were destroyed after having been translated into Castilian.<ref name=EC140630/> *That [[Teresa of Ávila|Saint Teresa of Ávila]] was actually Teressa Enrìques de Cardona, abbess at the [[Monastery of Pedralbes]] for thirty years.<ref name=ABC140614/><ref> {{cite news|first=José Ángel|last=Montañés| title = Sin rastro de Santa Teresa en el monasterio de Pedralbes|url=http://ccaa.elpais.com/ccaa/2014/12/24/catalunya/1419436345_910279.html|work= El País| language = Spanish|date=24 December 2014}}</ref> *That the first university founded in the Iberian Peninsula was the [[University of Barcelona]], rather than the universities of [[University of Salamanca|Salamanca]] and [[University of Palencia|Palencia]].<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2016-12-26/teorias-independentistas-universidad-de-barcelona-mas-antigua-que-salamanca_1309166/|title=La última teoría independentista: Barcelona ya tenía universidad antes que Salamanca|work=El Confidencial|date=26 December 2016|last=Fernández|first=Antonio|language=Spanish }}</ref> *That the design of the [[Flag of the United States|flag of the United States of America]] was inspired by the Catalan [[senyera]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Jordi|last=Bilbeny|title=Sobre l'origen de la bandera dels Estats Units d'Amèrica|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Sobre-l'origen-de-la-bandera-dels-Estats-Units-d'America|website=Institut Nova Història|language=Catalan|date=5 December 2010}}</ref>
==Support from Catalan nationalists== The INH is funded by the Catalan autonomous government.<ref name=Garín>{{cite book|last =Garín|first= Alberto|chapter=A Non-Manifesto of Liberal History|year=2018|editors= Douma, Michael J. and Magness, Phillip W.|title=What is Classical Liberal History|publisher= Lexington Books|location=Lanham, Md.|isbn=9781498536103|pages=211–212|url= https://books.google.co.ve/books?id=V19CDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA211&lpg#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> It has collaborated with the separatist [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|Catalan National Assembly]] in organising conferences on the history of Catalonia.<ref name=ABC140614>{{cite news|last=Guil|first= Janot|title=La Asamblea Nacional Catalana se apropia también de Santa Teresa de Jesús|url=http://www.abc.es/espana/20140611/abci-asamblea-nacional-catalana-apropia-201406102146.html | work=ABC|date=11 June 2014|language=SP}}</ref> In 2013 it was one of the recipients of the {{lang|ca|Premi Nacional President Lluís Companys}} (President Lluís Companys National Awards) by the [[Sants-Montjuïc]] branch of [[Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya]].<ref>{{cite news| title = L'Institut Nova Història serà guardonat amb el Premi Nacional President Lluís Companys|url=http://www.llibertat.cat/2013/10/l-institut-nova-historia-sera-guardonat-amb-el-premi-nacional-president-lluis-companys-23431 | work = llibertat.cat | date = 16 October 2013 | language = Catalan}}</ref> In 2012 the former president of the [[Generalitat de Catalunya]], [[Jordi Pujol]], wrote to Bilbeny congratulating him on his book ''Discovery and Catalan conquest of America. A history rewritten by the Castilians'', noting that the books published by the INH "are very convincing", while in 2014, the former vice-president of the Generalitat de Catalunya, [[Josep Lluís Carod-Rovira]], participated at the reissue of Bilbeny's ''Brief account of the destruction of history'', where he spoke in praise of the book.<ref name=EC140804>{{cite news|last=Fernández|first=A.|title=Jordi Pujol y Carod se suman a la teoría de que Colón y los Pinzón eran catalanes|url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2014-07-03/jordi-pujol-y-carod-se-suman-a-la-teoria-de-que-colon-y-los-pinzon-eran-catalanes_155815/|work=El Confidencial|date=3 July 2014|language = Spanish}}</ref>
The 2015 INH symposium in [[Arenys de Munt]], under the title "The Catalan Discovery of America", was financed by the councils of Arenys de Munt and [[Arenys de Mar]], together with associations such as the {{lang|ca|Ateneu Independentista}} of Arenys de Munt. [[Muriel Casals i Couturier|Muriel Casals]], representative of the separatist coalition [[Junts pel Sí]], gave the closing speech entitled "From the erased past to political independence".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ruiz Coll|first=M.A.|title=ERC reúne a 40 historiadores con dinero público para demostrar que Da Vinci, Marco Polo, Colón y Cervantes eran catalanes|url=https://okdiario.com/espana/cataluna/2015/11/25/erc-reune-a-40-historiadores-con-dinero-publico-para-demostrar-que-da-vinci-marco-polo-colon-y-cervantes-eran-catalanes-28378|work=ok diario| language=Spanish|date=25 November 2015}}</ref>
INH members have given talks on their theories in the main Catalan government-owned television and radio channels such as [[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]] and [[Catalunya Ràdio]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ccma.cat/tv3/alacarta/el-documental/desmuntant-leonardo/video/5561885/|title=Desmuntant Leonardo|author=[[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Prkiy0K0Cuk|publisher=youtube|title=Entrevista Mònica Terribas: Bilbeny/Grau (1/4) histocat.cat}}</ref><ref name="El Punt"/><ref name="Cat Radio"/>
==Criticism== The INH has been described by one academic as "a group of Catalan self-styled scholars trying to prove and promote the idea that, throughout History, a massive conspiracy by the Crown of Castille, the Inquisition, and any institution that may be related to Castille, has been orchestrated against the nation of Catalonia to deprive it of its History and cultural identity in order to promote Castile".<ref name=Rodríguez>{{cite journal |last=Rodríguez López-Abadía |first=Arturo |date=2014 |title=The origins of Christopher Columbus, a never-ending controversy |url=https://www.academia.edu/9952462/The_origins_of_Christopher_Columbus_a_never-ending_controversy |journal=Revista Internacional Digilec|volume=Vol. 1|number=1|pages=1 to 10 |issn=2386-6691|access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref> It was criticised in the Catalan parliament by the opposition party [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Ciudadanos]] spokeswoman, Carina Mejías, who described its theories as "ridiculous".<ref>{{cite news|last=Sallés|first=Quico|title = C's: «És ridícul dir que Cristòfol Colom és català»|url=http://www.naciodigital.cat/noticia/67614/es/ridicul/dir/cristofol/colom/catala|work= NacióDigital.cat|date =22 April 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref> Javier Barraycoa, vice-chancellor of the [[Abat Oliba CEU University]], former secretary of the {{ill|Carlist Traditionalist Communion|ca|Comunió Tradicionalista Carlista}} in Catalonia,<ref>{{cite web|title= Directorio General de la Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista|url=http://www.carlistas.es/descargas/organigrama.pdf|website=Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista| language=Spanish|date=January 2013}}</ref> and member of the anti-Catalanist organisation [[Somatemps]], said that the INH "has absolutely no recognition in the academic world" and that its members "have not been invited to any serious congress because it is impossible for them to defend these things."<ref>{{cite news|last=Moreno|first=Rosalina|title=Barraycoa: ‘Cataluña vive un delirio colectivo’|url=http://www.gaceta.es/noticias/cataluna-vive-delirio-colectivo-10072014-1128|work=La Gaceta |date=10 July 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref>
